thread.title: Cavaliers fall to 76ers on last-second three
thread.title_full: Cavaliers fall to 76ers on last-second three

title: Cavaliers fall to 76ers on last-second three
text:
Cavaliers fall to 76ers on last-second three The Cleveland Cavaliers fell to the Philadelphia 76ers on a last-second three-pointer tonight in Philadelphia. Post to Facebook Cavaliers fall to 76ers on last-second three The Cleveland Cavaliers fell to the Philadelphia 76ers on a last-second three-pointer tonight in Philadelphia.  //on.wkyc.com/1RwWC9o   Join the Conversation To   Cavaliers fall to 76ers on last-second three Matthew Florjancic, WKYC 9:57 p.m. EDT October 8, 2015 The Cleveland Cavaliers fell to the Philadelphia 76ers on a last-second three-pointer tonight in Philadelphia. The Cleveland Cavaliers fell to the Philadelphia 76ers on a last-second three-pointer tonight in Philadelphia. (Photo: Bill Streicher-USA TODAY Sports) CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Scottie Wilbekin took just one shot for the Philadelphia 76ers in their preseason game against the Cleveland Cavaliers, but he certainly made it count in front of the home fans, as he knocked down a three-pointer from the top of the key that capped off a 115-114 come-from-behind win. 
With nine seconds left in the game, Cavaliers (0-2) guard Jared Cunningham caught an inbounds pass and attempted to dribble up the sideline, but was whistled for an offensive foul when he swung his guard hand and made contact with the head of a Philadelphia defender Then, Wilbekin took a handoff around a screen and pulled up for the game-winning shot for the 76ers (1-1). 
The late foul spoiled what was an otherwise good night for Cunningham and the Cavaliers. 
A first-round pick of the Cavaliers (1-1) in the 2012 NBA Draft, Cunningham converted eight of his 10 attempts from the field, two of his three three-point shots, and went 13 of 16 from the free-throw line in scoring a game-best 31 points in the loss. In 31 minutes of action, Cunningham not only scored 31 points, but also, pulled down four rebounds and handed out three assists. 
In addition to Cunningham, center Anderson Varejao (10 points), guard/forward D.J. Stephens (11) and guard Matthew Dellavedova (13) scored in double figures in the loss. 
Early in the game, Varejao came off the bench, and then, knocked down five of his seven shots from the field, en route to a 10-point performance in the first quarter. In addition to his 10 points, Varejao pulled down three rebounds and handed out an assist in just over six minutes of action. 
Varejao's assist came when he took a pass from Dellavedova while rolling to the hoop, and skipped a pass into the left corner of the floor, where Cunningham caught the ball, squared himself up to the hoop and buried a 23-foot three-point shot, which gave the Cavaliers a 22-13 lead over the 76ers with 3:48 to play in the first quarter. 
In the final 61 seconds of play in the first quarter, Varejao made a trio of jump shots, including back-to-back attempts from 20 and 17 feet, respectively. 
The Cavaliers followed up the solid first-quarter production with more offensive prowess in the second period. 
While the 76ers struggled shooting the ball and made only nine of their 23 attempts, the Cavaliers converted 12 of their 23 shots, including a three-of-eight mark from three-point range, which allowed Cleveland to hold a 34-30 edge in scoring in the second quarter and take a 65-54 lead into halftime. 
Cunningham caught fire for the Cavaliers in the second quarter, and converted four of his five attempts from the field, including one of his two three-point shots, and made six of his seven shots at the free-throw line, en route to scoring a team-best 15 points in the period. 
The Cavaliers built their lead over the 76ers to 15 points, 89-74, by outscoring Philadelphia, 24-20, in the third quarter. 
Already up by 11 points heading into the third quarter, the Cavaliers ballooned their advantage to 17 points, 71-54, with three quick baskets out of the halftime break. 
After small forward James Jones buried a 20-foot jump shot on the opening possession of the third quarter, fellow forward Richard Jefferson stole a ball, and later, caught a pass from Dellavedova before pulling up for a 16-foot jumper. Point guard Mo Williams staked the Cavaliers out to the 17-point lead when he buried an 18-foot pull-up jumper of his own with 10:29 to play in the period. Read or Share this story: http://on.wkyc.com/1RwWC9o TOP VIDEOS
